Diaminosilane-functionalized on silicate-stabilised hydrotalcite (MA-HTSi-DA): As potential catalyst for nitro-aldol condensation Baskaran Thangaraj a Christopher Jayaraj b Radhakrishnan Srinivasan c Sakthivel Ayyamperumal a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Laboratory, University of Delhi, New Delhi 110007, India Department of Chemistry Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Laboratory University of Delhi New Delhi 110007 India b Indian Oil Corporation Ltd., R&D Centre, Faridabad 121007, India Oil Corporation Ltd. R&D Centre Faridabad 121007 India c NMR Lab, CSIR-Central Electrochemical Research Institute, Karaikudi 630006, India NMR Lab CSIR-Central Electrochemical Research Institute Karaikudi 630006 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract First time, diaminosilane was introduced into silicate-anion-intercalated hydrotalcite using post-synthesis method. The functionalised materials were systematically investigated through powder XRD, FT-IR and MAS–NMR studies. The materials showed very good catalytic activity on nitroaldol condensation of benzaldehyde and nitromethane. Diaminosilane was introduced into silicate-anion-intercalated hydrotalcite (HT-Si) using a post-synthesis method. The resulting functionalized materials possess surface basicity. The textural properties of the functionalized materials were systematically investigated through powder XRD, FTIR and MAS–NMR studies. The diamine-functionalized materials showed very good catalytic activity for the nitro-aldol condensation of benzaldehyde and nitromethane under solvent-free conditions. The materials showed comparable catalytic activity upon recycling. Keywords Hydrotalcite Diamine functionalization Silicate intercalated hydrotalcite Nitro-aldol condensation Functionalization 1 Introduction The functionalization of inorganic support materials using various functional ligands such as mercaptyl, amino propyl and diamine has received great research interest in recent decades, owing to the formation of hybrid materials, which may be useful for diverse applications [1–10]. Among the various materials, amine-functionalized silica, polymers, carbon materials and so forth, have shown a strong ability to bond with metals ions, to capture CO2 and have been important in base-catalyzed reactions [11,12]. In particular, amine-functionalized mesoporous silicate materials such as SBA-15, MCM and HMS (hexagonal mesoporous silica) were used in various applications, such as condensation reactions (aldol, nitro-aldol, Knoevenagel and Claisen–Schmidt), Michael additions, CC bond formation and as adsorbents, etc. [5–10,13,14]. The double layered hydroxides or hydrotalcite like materials (HT) are another class of supporting materials [15–19], which yield active mixed oxides through the calcination. The resultant mixed oxides derived from HT are used in various fields, such as adsorbents, drug delivery, sensors, ion exchangers, electrode modifiers, catalysts and so forth [20–22]. Modified hydrotalcite materials were used for various base-catalyzed condensation and organic transformation reactions [23–27]. However, reproduction of catalytic activity on multi-metal oxide derived from HT is a challenging task. The layered structure of HT collapses upon calcination between 200 and 400°C owing to dehydration, dehydroxylation and decarboxylation. For example, calcination and activation of hydrotalcite materials results thermal migration of cations into tetrahedral positions and formation of spinel type oxide which is disable to reconstruction of layered structure [28–29]. In this regards, recently, we have shown that these interlayer spaces can be rejoined by introducing hard anions (such as silicate) and they have been shown as promising catalysts and catalytic supports, owing to the their intrinsic properties [30–32]. The nitro-aldol condensation is an important base catalyzed reaction used in pharmaceuticals as well in various organic syntheses. In particular, nitro-alkenes are versatile intermediates in organic synthesis and in the chemical industry [33–35], Conventionally these reactions were studied using various catalysts such as NaY zeolite [36], magnesium aluminium oxide derived from HT [37], hydrotalcite in ionic liquid medium [38], MgAl–O–tBu [39], functionalized SBA-15 [40], SBA-15/Cu-complex [41], hetero bi-metallic complexes [42], Co(II) Salen catalyst [43], etc. We believe that the introduction of reactive diamine functionality on silicate-intercalated stable layered MA-HT materials (MA–HTSi–DA) might enhance the strong basicity, which are derived from both HT support and the diamine functionality. Here with we report the synthesis of diamine functionalized silicate-anion-intercalated hydrotalcite (Scheme 1 ). The synthesized materials were systematically characterized by various analytical and spectroscopic techniques. The basicity of the materials is utilized for nitro-aldol condensation reaction in a liquid phase medium. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of HT and diamine functionalization Magnesium aluminium-hydrotalcite was synthesized by reported procedure [30,32,44] with molar composition of 1Mg: 0.33Al: 0.67 (NH4)2CO3: 3.27NH4OH: 125H2O and denoted as MA-HT. Silicate intercalated hydrotalcite was obtained as per the procedure mentioned earlier [32] by introducing 1.42M sodium silicate solution into the hydrotalcite gel having molar composition of 1Mg: 0.33Al: 0.67 (NH4)2CO3: 3.27NH4OH: 125H2O at room temperature with constant stirring. The resultant silicate intercalated hydrotalcite materials was filtered and washed with deionized water. The final materials were dried at 100°C and represented as MA-HTSi. For comparison, cobalt aluminium and zinc aluminum containing hydrotalcite were prepared with molar gel composition of 1Co: 0.33Al: 0.67 (NH4)2CO3: 3.27NH4OH: 125H2O and 1Zn: 0.33Al: 0.67 (NH4)2CO3: 3.27NH4OH: 125H2O, respectively [32,44], which are represent as CA-HT and ZA-HT. Further, the silicate intercalated CA-HT and ZA-HT having similar silicate concentration (1.42M) was prepared in a similar procedure described as above and final samples are represented as CA-HTSi and ZA-HTSi, respectively. Various siliane such as N-[3-(trimethoxysilyl) propyl] ethylenediamine, 3-aminopropyltri-ethoxysilane, 3-anilinopropyltri-methoxysilane are obtained from Sigma–Aldrich and utilized as received form without any further purification. Diamine functionalized MA-HTSi was prepared by treating MA-HTSi sample with N-[3-(Trimethoxysilyl) propyl] ethylenediamine [45]. First, MA-HTSi was pre-activated at 110°C for overnight under vacuum in a Schlenk round bottom flask. Then the activated material was cooled to room temperature and different concentration of N-[3-(Trimethoxysilyl) propyl] ethylenediamine was introduced and refluxed using dry toluene (30ml/g support) for 24h in nitrogen atmosphere. The different amount of diamine 0.0012, 0.0046, 0.0092 and 0.0138mol (0.25, 1–3ml, respectively), per gram has been functionalized on MA-HTSi materials. The final reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature and toluene was removed by vacuum filtration. The excess diamine was removed by washing with dichloromethane (DCM) several times and the solid was finally dried under vacuum. The diamine functionalized MA-HTSi materials are labelled as MA-HTSi-DA1, MA-HTSi-DA2, MA-HTSi-DA3 and MA-HTSi-DA4 (range from 0.0012–0.0138mol/g), respectively. For comparison, aliphatic aminosilane (3-aminopropyl) tri-ethoxysilane (0.0138mol/g) and aromatic aminosilane(3-anilinopropyl) tri-methoxysilane(0.0138mol/g) were grafted on MgAl-hydrotalcite as per the above described method and are represented as MA-HTSi-PA4 and MA-HTSi-PAn4, respectively. Also N-[3-(Trimethoxysilyl) propyl] ethylenediamine(0.0138mol/g) were grafted on silicate intercalated different hydrotalcite materials such as CA-HTSi and ZA-HTSi using similar procedure mentioned above and represented as CA-HTSi-DA4 and ZA-HTSi-DA4, respectively. 2.2 Characterization Powder XRD was performed to determine the crystallinity of the materials using a 8KW (Rigaku, Japan) diffractometer with Cu–Kα radiation (λ =1.5418Å). The diffraction patterns were recorded in the 2θ range 5–70°, with a scan speed and step size of 0.5°/min and 0.02°, respectively. FT-IR spectra were obtained with KBr pellets a Brüker, TENSOR 27 FT-IR Spectrometer. The textural properties such as BET surface area, pore volumeand pore diameter of the samples were derived from N2sorption analysis. The measurement was carried out at −196°C out using automatic micropore physisorption analyzer (Micromeritics ASAP 2020, USA). The samples were degassed at 110°C for at least 8h under 10−3 Torr pressure prior to each run. The solid-state CP-MAS NMR experiments were carried out on a Bruker AVANCE 400 narrow bore spectrometer equipped with a superconducting magnet with a field of 9.4 T using a 4mm double resonance cross-polarized magic angle spinning (CP-MAS) probe operating at resonating frequencies of 79.4 and 100.6MHz for 29Si and 13C, respectively. The samples were packed in 4mm zirconia rotors and subjected to a spinning speed of 5kHz: single pulse experiment with pulse duration of 4s and a relaxation delay time of 5s were used for recording 29Si and 13C MAS NMR pattern with 2000 number of scans. Thermogravimetry-analysis (TGA) was carried out in a Thermal Analyzer (Model-2950, TA Instruments, USA). About 5–10mg of the sample was taken in the platinum pan and heated in air at the heating rate of 10°C min−1 up to 800°C. 2.3 Catalytic studies Amino silane functionalized materials were studied for liquid phase nitro-aldol condensation in a round bottom flask. About 100mg of catalyst was loaded into the reaction mixture containing 1:3mole ratio of aldehyde (5mmol) and nitro methane (15mmol). The flask was charged into required temperature for an appropriate time. After completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture was filtered and analyzed using gas chromatography equipped with FID (Agilent 7890A Series) connected to a HP-5 capillary column (30m; HP-5). The products were confirmed through 1H NMR. For the comparison, the reaction was also studied on various HT, the amine functionalized HT and without catalyst under identical conditions. 3 Results and discussion FTIR spectra of pure and diamine-functionalized silicate-intercalated hydrotalcite materials are shown in Fig. 1 and other amine functionalized materials are displayed in Fig. S1. All the spectra show vibrational bands around 1070 and 800cm−1, which correspond to SiOSi stretching of silicate species present on the interlayer [30–32,44–47]. A weak band observed around 1350cm−1 is related to the carbonate stretching frequency, which is also present in the interlayer [15,30–32]. The presence of aminosilane functionality on MA-HTSi materials can be evidenced from the observed new bands around 2950–2740 and 1480cm−1. These vibrational bands are attributed to CH stretching and bending vibration of the propyl group present on the silane linker attached to the MA-HTSi samples. An additional peak observed around 1570cm−1 confirms the presence of the amine functionality on the surface of the MA-HTSi-DA samples. The relative intensity of the peaks corresponds to CH and NH vibration is increases with increasing loading of aminosilane [45,48]. Furthermore, all of the materials show a band at 600cm−1, owing to the MO or MOM vibrations in the layered framework [15,30–32]. The powder XRD patterns of silicate-intercalated and diaminosilane-functionalized materials are shown in Fig. 2 . In all cases, the peaks evident around 2θ of 12°, 23° and 33° are characteristic of the (003) (006) and (009) planes of layered hydrotalcite materials, respectively [15,16,30–32,44]. The broadening of the XRD peaks was observed on both silicate-intercalated and diamine-functionalized materials, which is attributed to the orientation of polymeric silicate anions and to the aminosilane group present in the interlayer of hydrotalcite [30–32,44–47]. Similar trend was evident on the HT materials obtained with different amine functionality (Fig. 2). The interlayer distance of grafted hydrotalcite was calculated based on the (003) plane and the results are summarized in Table 1 . The interlayer distance of MA-HTSi is 8.2Å, which is higher than the parent hydrotalcite (MA-HT; 7.85Å), owing to slight lattice expansion of the HT layers along the c axis. The introduction of diaminosilane functionality on various HT materials does not change the unit cell parameter, which indicates diamine functionality on the exposed surface through interlayer silicates. The N2 sorption isotherms of silicate-intercalated and amine-functionalized MA-HTSi materials are shown in Fig. 3 . All of the materials exhibited multilayer and type IV isotherms [30–32]. The isotherms of diamine functionalized various HT materials and various amine functionalized materials are shown in Fig S2. The silicate-intercalated material showed a BET surface area of 380m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 1.0cm3 g−1. The reduction in surface area and pore volume of amine-functionalized MA-HTSi materials signifies successful grafting of the diaminosilane moiety (Table 1). The silicon and carbon environments of the amine-functionalized materials were studied by 29Si and 13C CP-MAS NMR spectroscopy. The 29Si MAS NMR spectrum of MA-HTSi-DA4 (Fig. 4 A) shows chemical shift values around −115, −106 and −99ppm, corresponding to Si(OSi)n(OH)4–n species where n =0–2. These peaks are assigned as Q4, Q3 and Q2 sites, and in case of MA-HTSi-DA4, it is predominantly the Q4 and Q3 sites that are evident [30,32,45–47]. Further, MA-HTSi-DA4 exhibits an additional peak around −53ppm, which is characteristic of an organosilica environment (T sites) obtained by the covalent grafting of diaminosilane on the surface of MA-HTSi. In the 13C CP-MAS NMR spectrum (Fig. 4B), MA-HTSi-DA4 showed signals at 9, 20, 37 and 49ppm, which are characteristic of an alkyl linker being present in the diaminosilane [45,49,50]. Additionally, an unexpected peak was observed around 163ppm for the MA-HTSi-DA4 sample, corresponding to carbamic acid functionality. The observed carbamic acid carbonyl peak may be attributed to atmospheric CO2 interactions with the diamine functionality present on the MA-HTSi-DA4 surface [45]. The above fact confirms that organosilica groups are covalently bonded with silica moieties of intercalated HT materials. The thermal stability of amine-functionalized HT materials was studied by thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA). The parent (MA-HT) material shows (Fig. S3) typical weight losses corresponding to physisorbed water molecules and the decomposition of carbonate anions present in the interlayer [16,38]. The silicate-intercalated material (MA-HTSi) showed a relatively low weight loss (about 35%) compared to the parent HT material (51%), which supports the hypothesis that the silicate species were successfully intercalated between the inter-layers. The amine-functionalized material (MA-HTSi-DA4) showed little difference in weight loss (about 37%) to MA-HTSi (35%), owing to the decomposition of amine functional groups in the materials. The catalytic activity of the diamine-functionalised material (MA-HTSi-DA) was evaluated in the nitro-aldol condensation reaction in liquid-phase medium. A representation of the nitro-aldol condensation is shown in Scheme 2 . Various reaction parameters, such as temperature, time, aminosilane loading, various HT support and different amine functional groups present on the support, were systematically studied. In all cases, dehydrated 1-(2-nitro-vinyl) benzene (1) and the aldol 2-nitro 1-phenyl ethanol (2) were formed as major and minor products, respectively. Fig. 5 a displays the effect of the reaction time at various temperatures. At low temperature (40°C), the conversion gradually increases with time, reaching a maximum of about 70% after around 6h (Fig. 5a). An increase in reaction temperature (60–80°C) leads to about 50–70% conversion being obtained within 1h, and complete conversion was observed at 2h. In all cases, 1-(2-nitro-vinyl) benzene was obtained as the major product (more than 99%). The best catalytic activity was achieved at 70°C within 2h; thus, all further studies were carried out at 70°C for 2h. Kinetic study on nitro-aldol condensation reaction was studied at different temperature and results are shown in Fig 5b. The rate of reaction was steadily increases with increase in reaction temperature. The reaction appears to be first order with respect to benzaldehyde since a logarithmic plot of concentration [A] versus time is linear. The activation energy for the nitro-aldol condensation is obtained using Arrhenius plot, by plotting the log k versus 1/T (Fig. 5c). The activation energy of nitro-aldol condensation reaction was found to be 48KJ mol−1 which is comparable to literature value [51] and indicates that the reaction does not have any diffusion limitation. The effect of the concentration of the diaminosilane loading on the surface and its catalytic activities over catalysts possessing different diamine concentration (0.0012, 0.0046, 0.0092 and 0.0138molg–1) was investigated and the results are displayed in Fig. 6 . As the loading of diamine functionality increased, the conversion increased steadily and a maximum conversion and selectivity was evident for MA-HTSi-DA4. The selectivity of 1-(2-nitro-vinyl) benzene remains more than 90% in all cases. In order to estimate the turn over frequency (TOF) diamine functionalized catalysts were studied the catalytic reaction till the conversion level reaches 90% using 5mmol of substrate and 100mg of catalysts. The catalysts with diammine concentration of 0.0012, 0.0046 and 0.0092M yielded 90% conversion of nitro-aldol at 70°C, with the reaction duration of 36, 12 and 6h respectively. Based on the above results, the corresponding TOF was found to be around 1h–1 for the catalyst possessing lower diamine loading (between 0.0012 to 0.0092molg–1). The catalyst with maximum diammine loaded (0.013M) sample showed complete conversion at 2h, with the TOF of 1.8h–1. The presence of a maximum number of active sites (0.013mol.g–1) and the high surface area (Table 1) in MA-HTSi-DA4 facilitate mono-layer distribution of active sites and favor the maximum conversion with better TOF. Furthermore, the reaction was also studied on various supports, with and without diamine functionality, and the results are summarized in Table 2 . The reaction did not proceed without a catalyst (GC data Fig. S4). Further, the pure as-prepared hydrotalcite showed about 31% conversion with equal distribution of products 1 and 2. The presence of weak basicity derived from surface hydroxyl group on parent support material responsible for poor selectivity of 1 observed on pure HT. Furthermore, silicate-intercalated hydrotalcite MA-HTSi showed low conversions of only about 1%. The reactivity enhances only when amine functionality was present on the layered stable hydrotalcite support. The presence of amine functionality on hydrotalcite materials improves catalytic activity on nitro-aldol condensation reaction. To understand the role of the diaminosilane support, it was also functionalized on different silicate-intercalated HTs such as cobalt-aluminium (CA-HTSi-DA4) and zinc aluminium (ZA-HTSi-DA4), and the catalytic activities were evaluated. CA-HTSi-DA4 and ZA-HTSi-DA4 showed about 70 and 36% conversion, respectively. The presence of surface redox-active species with cobalt and a Lewis acidic Zn center do not favor the catalytic activity. Furthermore, the reaction was also tested with different aminosilane-functionalized MA-HTSi, such as aliphatic amine (3-aminopropyl) tri-ethoxysilane (MA-HTSi-PA4) and aromatic amine (3-anilinopropyl) tri-methoxysilane (MA-HTSi-PAn4). The catalytic results are shown in Table 3 . MA-HTSi-PAn4 does not show any conversion under identical conditions and only it shows 45% conversion at 90°C, which may be attributed to the delocalization of electron inside the ring, and does not facilitate the formation of imine intermediate, thus showing a lower conversion. The mono-amine-functionalized material MA-HTSi-PA4 showed only 61% conversion. Further, diaminosilane functionalized silica material (SBA-15) was tested for catalytic activity under identical conditions and showed only 32% conversion, which is lower than diaminosilane functionalized hydrotalcite materials. The diaminosilane-functionalized materials (MA-HTSi-DA4) yielded a maximum conversion of 96% with a selectivity of 99.5% 1-(2-nitro-vinyl) benzene. The observed higher conversion could be attributed to the strong basicity derived from the diamine functionality associate with HT support on the present materials. It is known from the previously published reports that the nitro-aldol condensation can follow two types of mechanism, that is, the imine or ion-pair mechanism to yield dehydrated and alcohol products, respectively [50–53]. The possible mechanism of the nitro-aldol condensation is proposed and shown in Scheme 3 . In the first step, the amines present on the surface interacting with the carbonyl groups of the aldehyde. In the second step, an imine intermediate is formed and followed by dehydration; subsequently, nitro methane reacts with intermediate imine to produce dehydrated products. The higher conversion was observed due to the close proximity of the hydroxyl group and amine sites in the functionalized materials. The reaction was further studied using different substituted aromatic, aliphatic and heterocyclic aldehydes under optimum conditions. The results are summarized in Table 4 . In all the cases, a conversion of 85–90% was evident; however, the reactions of substituted aldehydes proceeded for longer durations compared to non-substituted aldehydes. In all cases, a conversion level of more than 80% was achieved with exclusive formation of the dehydrated product. The nature of the substituent on the benzene ring and the nature of the ring (aromatic or heterocyclic) in the aldehydes did not affect the conversion. Heterocyclic aldehydes also (indole-3-carboxaldehyde; Table 3, entry 8) shows 88% conversion with 98% selectivity of dehydrated product. The use of aliphatic aldehyde result in relative less conversion compare to aromatic aldehydes. The low reactivity of aliphatic aldehyde may results in relatively lower conversion. After each reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture and washed with dichloromethane and dried well before the recycling studies. The catalyst retains about 70% of its initial activity even after three recycles; the slight decrease in conversion is due to the blocking of active sites by the chemisorbed products. In addition the considerable decrease in product 1 selectivity on recycled catalyst might also due to masking of some of the basic sites by chemisorbed organic (reactant and product) molecules and thus conversion of product 2 into 1 is limited. The FT-IR spectrum of a spent catalyst was (Fig. S5) indicated that the increase in relative intensity of peaks corresponds to CH vibrations (1500–1400cm–1 range), derived from chemisorbed organic present in the support. Further, weak symmetric and asymmetric vibrational bands of nitro group also evident around 1300cm–1, which comes from products. An additional peak appeared around 1517cm–1, which corresponds to the bending NH vibration [54] also supports the presence of functional group present in the spent catalyst [55]. 4 Conclusions In summary, silicate-anion-intercalated hydrotalcite was synthesized and functionalized with diaminosilane groups. The composition of the functionalized materials was confirmed by FT-IR and MAS-NMR techniques. The materials show better conversion than the parent hydrotalcite materials in the nitro-aldol condensation reaction in liquid-phase medium. The catalysts contain the amine with silanol groups, enhancing the catalytic efficiency on nitro-aldol condensation. Acknowledgements Authors thank DU-DST Purse grants (Ref. No. CD/2015/1534), University of Delhi, India for their financial support, and USIC, University of Delhi, India for analytical support. We thank Prof. Ramesh C. Deka for his valuable scientific discussion. coredata.dc:description: Diaminosilane was introduced into silicate-anion-intercalated hydrotalcite (HT-Si) using a post-synthesis method. The resulting functionalized materials possess surface basicity. The textural properties of the functionalized materials were systematically investigated through powder XRD, FTIR and MAS–NMR studies. The diamine-functionalized materials showed very good catalytic activity for the nitro-aldol condensation of benzaldehyde and nitromethane under solvent-free conditions. The materials showed comparable catalytic activity upon recycling.
coredata.dc:title: Diaminosilane-functionalized on silicate-stabilised hydrotalcite (MA-HTSi-DA): As potential catalyst for nitro-aldol condensation
